content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Contribution qui permet de tester le niveau de compréhension et d'analyse.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: very interesting

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: This is horrible for reverse mode! Keep in mind, you don't see the title or the goal statement in reverse, so there's no hint.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like that this one is a little different and a little tongue in cheek. Well done!
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I have updated the validators which are now different from the tests.

I've added hints so it's not too complicated.

The example allows to find the pattern without the clues : multiplication by 0 on the first term & multiplication by 1 on the second term allows to see the ².

Please let me know if I can improve the exercise.

Thank you very much

I would update the statement in a way to let users understand that in your equation the 'c' is not a constant, but part of input. Add some sci-fi small talk - like "Imagine if the speed of light could be variable?(Parallel universes xD)" - of course you can write a better explanation, but you got my idea.

As tselebr mentioned, "c" is a constant in Einstein's equation. As a result, the question becomes unclear. However, I think the concept is really fun. Perhaps you could change to a single input/output? That way, the coders will have to puzzle out the fact that the input is being multiplied by c^2? Do you think this makes the problem too easy?
ok
I like the idea, but as a physicist I want to note that the speed of light is a constant. Doubled kinetic energy is calculated in your solution.

I liked the idea, but I think it can be improved:
      1- Add more clues (maybe in a commented line or in the introduction)
      2- Add coding related test cases, e.g. give float inputs and expect rounded int

It is "find the pattern" clash.
It will teach you nothing in regards to coding.
Test cases beside the first one are bad - brings nothing at the table.
I had a hard time to find the pattern without looking at the title, but still a good one!

Adapted from the clash of code reverse, I wrote this one to enhance the quick clashes that require quick thinking about the problem.

Please comment when a negative or positive vote that I can improve myself and improve the contribution.

Thank you in advance

Maybe I can add a line on the example "0 2 -> 0" to understand that is a multiplication between a & b^2 ?

I had many downvote maybe because it's not obvious and this fix can help to resolv the problem fastly.

Thank you !

Indeed, I tried to realize a speed exercise in "reverse engineering" / logic mode.

During recruitment in companies, it is common to see this kind of test, I find it interesting to have some among the clashes of code.

Thanks for your feedback.
I agree with the first mark, but the second one will be too difficult to find the pattern.

At the beginning I wanted to do a reverse engineering exercise or rather a logic exercise.
Since the equations are sometimes far-fetched, I decided to take one that everyone knows...
It's true that physically it doesn't mean much, but here most of the coders are not physicists...

At the beginning I wanted to do a reverse engineering exercise or rather a logic exercise.
Since the equations are sometimes far-fetched, I decided to take one that everyone knows...
It's true that physically it doesn't mean much, but here most of the coders are not physicists...

I added a line to that effect in the statement :)

Thanks for your feedback
Do you think making the title "E=mc^2" makes the problem too easy?

I've seen much harder ones go by, without a clue!

The first line shows that there is a multiplication between the two terms.
The second line shows that the right term is squared.

Frankly, you don't need to be a genius either...

And thanks for the constructive comment!

yes maybe you should add a useful examples like : 
0 2
3 0
2 5
